<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_v2_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_v2_form (const void *cls,
                 const char *mime,
                 struct Session *session,
                 struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  size_t slen;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (SECOND_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1)
         + strlen (session->value_2);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            SECOND_PAGE,
            session->value_1,
            session->value_2);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            SECOND_PAGE,
            session->value_1,
            session->value_2);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If the format string SECOND_PAGE contains conversion specifications that are not a simple pair of %s replacements (for example extra %s specifiers, width/precision specifiers, or other conversions), the call can invoke undefined behaviour and may access memory out of bounds. Concrete examples: (1) SECOND_PAGE = "%s%s%s" — only two arguments are supplied, so the third %s causes snprintf to read an unintended pointer from the stack (out‑of‑bounds access). (2) SECOND_PAGE = "...%20s...%s..." — field width/precision or other format modifiers can make the produced output longer than the computed slen, leading to mismatch between allocated buffer and required content (and thus potential invalid accesses or truncation/UB depending on usage). Therefore the fragment can violate the rule.
